title: *OTY 2025
verdict: The year 2025 had its ups and downs for me (again) personally.
I played a lot more games on the PS5 compared to previous years, but I still finished 26 games on mobile, which is slightly above my average of 2 games per month.
Out of them, only 5 were actually released this year. So picking a GOTY is simple (or not?), but probably not objective.
Looking at other mobile GOTY lists, the good news is that I played most of the picks; I simply did not finish them (but plan to).
On the other hand, I finished some amazing leftovers (like Death's Door or A Monster's Expedition).
One trend I would like to mention—and I have to adapt to—is that most of the (from my point of view) best mobile games didn't get discounted heavily.
So next year, I will probably just buy those of interest to me right away (as I did for only a few this year).
So without further ado, my mobile GOTY of 2025 is... a split between Spooky Express
and Pine Hearts! Both were great in their own way.
As I mentioned in my thoughts, Spooky Express brings some of the most satisfying puzzles ever (and my name in the credits),
and Pine Hearts is just lovely overall and close to my heart due to the topic of fighting personal demons.
My video game music OTY is, without any hesitation, Absolum. I did not like a lot of Gareth's music since the second Ori, but this album just slaps!
The Green River and Dracoraptor Mountains combo are two of the best tracks I heard all year.
My movie OTY is F1. This year was about all kinds of F1-related things for me and my family (Hot Wheels, LEGO, etc.).
I did not expect much of the movie (and I'm definitely not a fan of the main actor), even though I liked Maverick a lot, but was pleasantly surprised.
Oh, and its soundtrack is very cool, too.

title: Coffee Pool
verdict: We have a saying in Slovakia that translates roughly to "exception proves the rule." As much as I dislike ads in games, every now and then I come across one I enjoy despite them.
As a former (semi-)professional pool billiards player, I'm a sucker for games inspired by the sport, like Smash Puck, Last Pocket, and more.
I consider Subpar Pool to be one of the best, though I haven't finished it yet.
And then came Coffee Pool...
I participated in the beta testing and immediately knew it was going to be a great one. After the official release, I was sure of it.
The game has excellent physics, precise aiming, and pocketing balls just feels right.
I really enjoy progressing through the various leagues, but when I don't have much time, I just play the daily break.
The folks at Shallot Games were kind enough to send me a promo code to remove the ads (so technically, I didn't break my "personal codex").
As far as I know, there's no way to actually "finish" the game, so I decided to write this blog post as a token of gratitude.
If you enjoy pool billiards-inspired games, you can't go wrong with this one. And if you don't believe me, you can always try it for yourself.

title: Art of Rally
verdict: "The only game that is both thrilling and relaxing at the same time." Those would have been my thoughts on the game, along with a shiny 5-star rating—if things hadn't gone sideways.
Unfortunately, they did, and I'm quite disappointed. Here's the full story:
I pre-ordered Art of Rally on iOS the second I learned it was coming, because I absolutely love its soundtrack. I listen to it a lot, mostly while driving my car.
It's my go-to album when I'm not in the mood for anything else. Once the game was released, I started playing through the career mode.
I knew it would take quite some time to finish, but I was in no rush. As new games were released, I played Art of Rally less, but I always came back to it.
As mentioned in my one-liner, the game had an almost meditative effect on me. It even helped me face some of my demons—which is a lot to say about a video game.
After almost 18 months, the long-awaited moment finally came: earning one of my most precious Game Center achievements—Master of Rally. But I never got it, due to a bug.
I immediately contacted the devs through various channels, but they ignored me at first.
When I finally heard back, they explained that only one person was handling customer support and that it would take time to get to my ticket. It's been three months since then...
So yes, I finished Art of Rally, but it's not officially on my list because I've been waiting for a fix or at least some guidance, but I ultimately ran out of patience.
The worrying part isn't just the bug—it's that a company currently porting games to mobile has such poor support.
This experience has completely destroyed my trust in Noodlecake, and I'm certain I won't be pre-ordering or paying full price for any of their future releases.

title: Finished GOTY 2024
verdict: Here are my overall top 5 games that I finished in 2024:
1. Spiritfarer
- I'm not really into managmenet (or gardening?) games, but this heartwarming gem helped me a lot to get through a quite difficult time.
Despite its heavy theme, it was pure joy to play it. And it's soundtrack is simply exceptional.
2. Transistor
- I was a huge fan of Bastion back in 2011, so I always considered this one a must-play. After finally finishing it this year, I consder it a masterpiece.
3. Braid, Anniversary Edition
- I never played the original and my brother did not quite finish it when it got released back in 2008...
Plus a former editor-in-chief of a gaming magazine once said that only really smart people can finish it without a guide.
All of this was additional motivation for me to finish it. Plus I could think about the levels even when not playing it which helped me a lot at that time.
4. Arranger
- Original, clever, funny, great looking and good sounding puzzling gem.
5. Paper Trail
- I had to came back to this one after some time, but then it clicked very well with me.
I loved the folding, the art style and the beatiful soundtrack I listen to from time to time ever since.
